evening_wind_down_article.title: The Art of the Evening Wind-Down
evening_wind_down_article.subtitle: Help your body and mind prepare for restful sleep.
evening_wind_down_article.intro: A consistent evening routine signals to your body that it's time to transition from the activity of the day to the rest of night. This wind-down practice helps reduce stress hormones and activate your parasympathetic nervous system for deeper, more restorative sleep.

why_it_matters.title: Why Evening Wind-Down Matters
why_it_matters.content: Your nervous system needs time to shift from the sympathetic 'go mode' to the parasympathetic 'rest mode.' Without this transition, your mind may stay active even when your body is tired, leading to poor sleep quality and increased stress the next day.

screen_dim.title: Screen dim
screen_dim.description: Lower your screen brightness or switch to night mode to signal to your brain that it's time to wind down.

body_scan_article.title: Quick Stress Relief: 3-Minute Body Scan
body_scan_article.subtitle: Regain calm in under 2 minutes.
body_scan_article.intro: When stress hits, your body's fight-or-flight response activates. These evidence-based techniques help quickly shift your nervous system back to a calmer state.

three_minute_body_scan.name: 3-Minute Body Scan
three_minute_body_scan.description: A quick scan to release tension and ground yourself in the present moment
steps: Close your eyes and take three deep breaths
Notice the top of your head and forehead - release any tension
Feel your shoulders and let them drop away from your ears
Scan through your chest, stomach, and back - breathe into any tightness
Notice your legs, knees, and feet - let them feel heavy and relaxed
Take a final deep breath and slowly open your eyes

bonus_practices.name: Hand-on-Heart
bonus_practices.description: A gentle self-soothing technique to activate your calming response
steps: Place one hand on your heart and one on your belly
Close your eyes and feel the warmth of your hands
Breathe slowly and deeply, feeling your chest and belly rise
Say to yourself: 'I am safe, I am calm, I am here'
Continue for 5-10 breaths, noticing the soothing effect

bonus_practices.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
bonus_practices.description: Use your senses to anchor yourself in the present moment
steps: 5 things you can SEE - Look around and name them
4 things you can FEEL - Notice textures, temperature
3 things you can HEAR - Listen to sounds around you
2 things you can SMELL - Take a moment to notice
1 thing you can APPRECIATE - Find something positive

bonus_practices.name: Affirmation Whisper
bonus_practices.description: Calm your nervous system with gentle self-reassurance
steps: Choose a calming phrase: 'This too shall pass' or 'I can handle this'
Whisper it to yourself slowly three times
Notice how your body relaxes with each repetition
Place your hand on your heart as you say it one final time

tips: Use these techniques as soon as you notice stress building
Find a quiet space where you won't be interrupted
Focus on the technique rather than the stressful situation
Practice regularly when calm to build your stress resilience
Remember: it's normal for your mind to wander - gently return focus

completion.title: Well Done!

completion.reminder: These techniques are most effective when practiced regularly. Even 2 minutes of stress relief can help reset your nervous system.

quick_stress_relief.title: Quick Stress Relief
quick_stress_relief.subtitle: Regain calm in under 2 minutes.
fallback_checklist: Take 5 deep breaths, counting each one
Drink a glass of water slowly
Step outside for fresh air if possible
Name 3 things you can see, 2 you can hear, 1 you can smell
Send a quick text to someone you care about
Write down what's stressing you, then set it aside

quick_stress_relief.note: If specific techniques aren't available, this checklist provides quick stress relief options.
